titleStmt.title: Compact finite difference method for the fractional diffusion equation

analytic.title: Compact finite difference method for the fractional diffusion equation

biblStruct.note: Received 28 April 2009 Received in revised form 17 July 2009 Accepted 23 July 2009

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Fractional diffusion equation Finite difference Compact scheme Padé approximant Stability Convergence Fourier analysis

div.p: High-order compact finite difference scheme for solving one-dimensional fractional diffusion equation is considered in this paper. After approximating the second-order derivative with respect to space by the compact finite difference, we use the Grünwald-Letnikov discretization of the Riemann-Liouville derivative to obtain a fully discrete implicit scheme. We analyze the local truncation error and discuss the stability using the Fourier method, then we prove that the compact finite difference scheme converges with the spatial accuracy of fourth order using matrix analysis. Numerical results are provided to verify the accuracy and efficiency of the proposed algorithm.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Fractional differential equations (FDEs) have attracted increasing attention because they have applications in various fields of science and engineering. For example, they can describe many physical and chemical processes, biological systems, etc. The main physical purpose for investigating diffusion equations of fractional order is to describe phenomena of anomalous diffusion in transport processes through complex and/or disordered systems including fractal media, and fractional kinetic equations have proved particularly useful in the context of anomalous slow diffusion, see, for example, the excellent review paper [1]. An overview of the basic theory of fractional differentiation, fractional-order differential equations, methods of their solution and applications can be found in the book [2].

There have been several numerical methods proposed for solving the space and/or time FDEs up to now. Lynch et al. [3] developed two numerical schemes, one explicit and another one semi-implicit, for solving the transport problem with anomalous diffusion modeled by a partial differential equation of fractional order. Meerschaert and Tadjeran [4] studied the onedimensional radial flow model, they found that the fractional derivative describes more accurately the early arrival that cannot be explained by the classical advection-dispersion equations and they presented an implicit Euler method, based on a @uðx; tÞ @t
div.formula: ¼ 0 D 1Àc t K c @ 2 u @x 2 " # þ f ðx; tÞ; x 2 ðL 0 ; L 1 Þ; 0 < t < T;ð1Þ
div.p: where K c is the generalized diffusion constant, and 0 D 1Àc t uð0 < c < 1Þ denotes the Riemann-Liouville fractional derivative of order 1 À c of the function vðx; tÞ, defined by [2], i.e., 0 D 1Àc t v ¼
CðcÞ @ @t Z t 0 vðx; sÞ ðt À sÞ 1Àc ds: ð2Þ
Note that in the limit c ! 1, the FDE (1) reduces to Fick's second law, and (1) corresponds to the ordinary (or Brownian) diffusion equation. The initial condition for (1) is uðx; 0Þ ¼ wðxÞ ð3Þ
and the Dirichlet boundary condition for (1) is given by (with uð0Þ ¼ wðL 0 Þ and wð0Þ ¼ wðL 1 Þ for consistency) uðL 0 ; tÞ ¼ uðtÞ; uðL 1 ; tÞ ¼ wðtÞ; t ! 0:
div.formula: ð4Þ
div.p: The paper is organized as follows: in Section 2, we present an implicit compact difference scheme. We approximate the second-order derivative with respect to space by the compact finite difference, then we use the Grünwald-Letnikov discretization for the approximation of the time fractional derivative. In Sections 3 the matrix form for the difference scheme is given, and the solvability for the linear system of equations is discussed. In Section 4 we give the local truncation error, investigate the stability by the Fourier method, and discuss the convergence of the scheme using matrix analysis, follow the paper by Zhao et al. [19]. We prove that the scheme is unconditionally stable for all c in the range 0 < c < 1, derive the global accuracy and prove the convergence of the scheme. Finally, some numerical results are provided in Section 5, they are in agreement with our theoretical analysis. The paper concludes with a summary in Section 6.
In this paper, the symbol C is a generic positive constant, it may take different value at different places. We use the ''empty sum" convention P q l¼p v l ¼ 0 for q < p.

div.head: Partition and the solution vector
div.p: For the numerical solution of the problem above we introduce a uniform grid of mesh points ðx j ; t k Þ, with x j ¼ L 0 þ jh; j ¼ 0; 1; . . . ; M and t k ¼ ks; k ¼ 0; 1; . . . ; N where M and N are positive integers, h ¼ ðL 1 À L 0 Þ=M is the mesh-width in x and s ¼ T=N the time step. The theoretical solution u at the point ðx j ; t k Þ is denoted by u k j . The solution of an approximating difference scheme at the same point will be denoted by U k j . We denote the exact solution vector of order N by
div.formula: u k ¼ uðt k Þ ¼ ðu k 1 ; . . . ; u k MÀ1 Þ T and the approximate solution vector U k ¼ Uðt k Þ ¼ ðU k 1 ; . . . ; U k MÀ1 Þ T .

div.head: Derivation of the numerical scheme
div.p: We give the numerical solution for the model problem 1, 3 and 4. As the familiar central difference quotient defined by 1
div.formula: h 2 d 2 x u j 1 h 2 ðu jÀ1 À 2u j þ u jþ1 Þ ¼ @ 2 u @x 2 ! j þ 112
@ 4 u @x 4 ! j h 2 þ Oðh 4 Þ ð5Þ
div.p: gives only second-order approximation to u xx , we can use the compact finite difference operator instead, and maintaining the three-point stencil. Introduce the central difference operator d x u j ¼ u jþ1=2 À u jÀ1=2 , then higher-order finite difference operators are derived from the approximation ((1-69) and (1-70) in [20])
div.formula: @ 2 u @x 2 ! j ¼ 2 h sinh À1 d x 2 ! 2 u j ¼ 1 h 2 d x À 1 2 2 2 Á 3! d 3 x þ 1 2 Á 3 2 2 4 Á 5! d 5 x À 1 2 Á 3 2 Á 5 2 2 6 Á 7! d 7 x þ Á Á Á " # 2 u j ¼ 1 h 2 d 2 x À 1 12 d 4 x þ 1 90 d 6 x À 1 560 d 8 x þ Á Á Á u j :
div.p: That is, we can use
div.formula: d 2 x h 2 1 þ 1 12 d 2 x À Áu k j ¼ 1 h 2 d 2 x À 1 12 d 4 x þ 1 144 d 6 x À 1 1728 d 8 x þ Á Á Á u k j ¼ @ 2 u @x 2 j k j À 1 240h 2 d 6 x u k j þ Oðh 6 Þ ¼ @ 2 u @x 2 j k j À 1 240 @ 4 u @x 4 j k j h 4 þ Oðh 6 Þ ð6Þ
div.p: to keep the fourth-order accuracy and the tridiagonal nature of the schemes.

Using the relationship between the Grünwald-Letnikov formula and the Riemann-Liouville fractional derivatives [2], we can approximate the fractional derivative by for k ! 1 and can be evaluated recursively,
div.formula: 0 D 1Àc t f ðtÞ ¼ 1 s 1Àc X ½t=s k¼0 xð1ÀcÞ
k f ðt À ksÞ þ Oðs p Þ;ð7Þ
x ðaÞ 0 ¼ 1; x ðaÞ k ¼ 1 À a þ 1 k xðaÞ
kÀ1 ; k ! 1:ð8Þ
div.p: See, for example, papers [6,21] for the details. For any function vðx; tÞ, we let v k j ¼ vðx j ; t k Þ and for the convenience of notations, we put these coefficients k l x ð1ÀcÞ l ¼ ðÀ1Þ l 1 À c l ; l ¼ 0; 1; . . . ; k. Then the implicit compact finite difference method for 1, 3 and 4 is given as follows:
div.formula: U k j ÀU kÀ1 j s ¼ K c s cÀ1 h 2 P k l¼0 k l d 2 x 1þ 1 12 d 2 x U kÀl j þ f k j ; j ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; M À 1; k ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; N; U 0 j ¼ wðx j Þ; j ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; M À 1; U k 0 ¼ uðt k Þ; U k M ¼ wðt k Þ; k ¼ 0; 1; . . . ; N: 8 > > > > > < > > > > > :ð9Þ

x À Á , after rearranging the terms and noting that k 0 ¼ 1, we have

div.formula: 1 12 À l À Á U 1 jÀ1 þ 5 6 þ 2l À Á U 1 j þ 1 12 À l À Á U 1 jþ1 ¼ 1 12 þ lk 1 À Á U 0 jÀ1 þ 5 6 À 2lk 1 À Á U 0 j þ 1 12 þ lk 1 À Á U 0 jþ1 þ s 1 12 f 1 jÀ1 þ 5 6 f 1 j þ 1 12 f 1 jþ1 ; 1 12 À l À Á U k jÀ1 þ 5 6 þ 2l À Á U k j þ 1 12 À l À Á U k jþ1 ¼ 1 12 þ lk 1 À Á U kÀ1 jÀ1 þ 5 6 À 2lk 1 À Á U kÀ1 j þ 1 12 þ lk 1 À Á U kÀ1 jþ1 þ l P kÀ2 l¼0 k kÀl ðU l jÀ1 À 2U l j þ U l jþ1 Þþs 1 12 f k jÀ1 þ 5 6 f k j þ 1 12 f k jþ1 ; 2 k N; U 0 j ¼ wðx j Þ; U k 0 ¼ uðt k Þ; U k M ¼ wðt k Þ; k ¼ 0;1;...;N: 8 > > > > > > > > < > > > > > > > > :ð11Þ

div.p: 3. Matrix form of the numerical scheme
Multiply the compact implicit difference approximation scheme (10) or ( 11) by a common factor 12, we can give the matrix form of the scheme by

div.p: For the solvability of the scheme we have Theorem 1. The difference system (10) has a unique solution.

Proof. Because for any l ¼ K c s c h 2 > 0, the coefficient matrix A for the difference equations is strictly diagonally dominant. Consequently, the matrix A is nonsingular, thus it is invertible. Therefore, the solution of our compact difference scheme exists and is unique. h 4. Theoretical analysis of the compact finite difference scheme

div.head: The local truncation error
div.p: We give the local truncation error of our scheme. First, we can use (7)
div.formula: to obtain 0 D 1Àc t f ðtÞ ¼ s cÀ1 X ½t=s l¼0 k l f ðt À lsÞ þ OðsÞ:ð13Þ
div.p: Therefore, let t ¼ ks and f ðtÞ 1, we get
div.formula: ðksÞ cÀ1 CðcÞ ¼ t cÀ1 CðcÞ ¼ 0 D cÀ1 t 1 ¼ s cÀ1 P k l¼0 k l þ OðsÞ.
div.p: That is, we obtain the following identity,
div.formula: s cÀ1 P k l¼0 k l ¼ t cÀ1
div.p: CðcÞ þ OðsÞ. 1 Hence the local truncation error of the scheme ( 10) is (note that 0 < c < 1)
div.formula: R k j ¼ u k j À u kÀ1 j s À K c s cÀ1 h 2 X k l¼0 k l d 2 x 1 þ 1 12 d 2 x u kÀl j À f k j ¼ u k j À u kÀ1 j s À @u @t j k j ! þ 0 D 1Àc t K c @ 2 u @x 2 " # k j À s cÀ1 X k l¼0 k l K c @ 2 u @x 2 j kÀl j 0 @ 1 A þ K c s cÀ1 Â X k l¼0 k l @ 2 u @x 2 kÀl j À d 2 x h 2 1 þ 1 12 d 2 x À Áu kÀl j 0 @ 1 A ¼ OðsÞ þ K c s cÀ1 X k l¼0 k l À 1 240 @ 4 u @x 4 j kÀl j h 4 þ Á Á Á ! ¼ OðsÞ þ OððksÞ cÀ1 h 4 Þ ¼ Oððk cÀ1 s cÀ1 þ 1Þðs þ h 4 ÞÞ:ð14Þ

div.head: . Stability
div.p: Stability analysis of the difference approximation scheme can be discussed by the Fourier method, as given in paper [7]. Let e U k j be the approximate solution of (10), and define
div.formula: q k j ¼ U k j À e U k j ; 1 j M À 1; 0 k N with corresponding vector q k ¼ ðq k 1 ; q k 2 ; . . . ; q k MÀ1 Þ T : Then we have 1 þ 1 12 À l d 2 x q k j À 1 þ 1 12 d 2 x q kÀ1 j ¼ l X k l¼1 k l d 2 x q kÀl j ; 1 j M À 1; 1 k N:ð15Þ
div.p: We expand q k into a piecewise constant function, that is, for k ¼ 0; 1; . . . ; N, we define the grid function
div.formula: q k ðxÞ ¼ 0; L 0 x L 0 þ h 2 ; q k j ; x j À h 2 < x x j þ h 2 ; j ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; M À 1; 0; L 1 À h 2 < x L 1 : 8 > < > :
div.p: We can expand q k ðxÞ in a Fourier series
div.formula: q k ðxÞ ¼ 1 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi L 1 À L 0 p X 1 m¼À1 c k ðmÞe i2pmðxÀL 0 Þ=ðL 1 ÀL 0 Þ ; 0 k N: For all w ¼ ðw 1 ; Á Á Á ; w MÀ1 Þ T 2 R MÀ1 ,
c k ðmÞ ¼ 1 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi L 1 À L 0 p Z L 1 L 0 e Ài2pmðnÀL 0 Þ=ðL 1 ÀL 0 Þ q k ðnÞdn
div.p: and we have Parseval's equality for the discrete Fourier transform, that is,
div.formula: Z L 1 L 0 jq k ðxÞj 2 dx ¼ X MÀ1 j¼1 hjq k j j 2 ¼ kq k k 2 l 2 ¼ X 1 m¼À1 jc k ðmÞj 2 :
div.p: Proof. The proof can be given similarly to those of Proposition 3.1.2 and 3.1.3 in book [22]. In fact, we have
div.formula: 1 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi L 1 À L 0 p Z L 1 L 0 e Ài2plðnÀL 0 Þ=ðL 1 ÀL 0 Þ q k ðnÞdn ¼ 1 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi L 1 À L 0 p Z L 1 L 0 e Ài2plðnÀL 0 Þ=ðL 1 ÀL 0 Þ 1 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi L 1 À L 0 p X 1 m¼À1 c k ðmÞe i2pmðnÀL 0 Þ=ðL 1 ÀL 0 Þ dn ¼ 1 L 1 À L 0 X 1 m¼À1 c k ðmÞ Z L 1 L 0 e i2pðmÀlÞðnÀL 0 Þ=ðL 1 ÀL 0 Þ dn ¼ 1 L 1 À L 0 X 1 m¼À1 m-l c k ðmÞ ðL 1 À L 0 Þ i2pðm À lÞ e i2pðmÀlÞðnÀL 0 Þ=ðL 1 ÀL 0 Þ ! j L 1 L 0 þ 1 L 1 À L 0 c kðlÞ

Z L 1 L 0 dn ¼ 1 L 1 À L 0 X 1 m¼À1 m-l c k ðmÞ ðL 1 À L 0 Þ i2pðm À lÞ ½e i2pðmÀlÞ À 1 þ c k ðlÞ ¼ c k ðlÞ and Z L 1 L 0 jq k ðxÞj 2 dx ¼ Z L 1 L 0 q k ðxÞq k ðxÞdx ¼ Z L 1 L 0 q k ðxÞ 1 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi L 1 À L 0 p X 1 m¼À1 c k ðmÞe i2pmðxÀL 0 Þ=ðL 1 ÀL 0 Þ dx ¼ 1 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi L 1 À L 0 p X 1 m¼À1 c kðmÞ

Z L 1 L 0 q k ðxÞe i2pmðxÀL 0 Þ=ðL 1 ÀL 0 Þ dx ¼ X 1 m¼À1 c k ðmÞ 1 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi L 1 À L 0 p Z L 1 L 0 e Ài2pmðxÀL 0 Þ=ðL 1 ÀL 0 Þ q k ðxÞdx ¼ X 1 m¼À1 c k ðmÞc k ðmÞ ¼ X 1 m¼À1 jc k ðmÞj 2
div.p: This finishes the proof. h

div.p: Lemma 3. Suppose that d k ð1 k NÞ are defined by ( 16), then for 0 < c < 1, we have jd k j jd 0 j; k ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; N:
Proof. We will use mathematical induction to complete the proof. For k ¼ 1, from the first equation in ( 16) we have

div.formula: jd k j 1 þ 4lð1 À cÞ sin 2 rh 2 1 þ 4l sin 2 rh 2 jd kÀ1 j þ 4l sin 2 rh 2 1 þ 4l sin 2 rh 2 X kÀ2 l¼0 jk kÀl jjd l j 1 þ 4lð1 À cÞ sin 2 rh 2 1 þ 4l sin 2 rh 2 jd 0 j þ 4l sin 2 rh 2 1 þ 4l sin 2 rh 2 X kÀ1 l¼0 jk kÀl j À jk 1 j ! jd 0 j 1 þ 4lð1 À cÞ sin 2 rh 2 1 þ 4l sin 2 rh 2 jd 0 j þ 4l sin 2 rh 2 1 þ 4l sin 2 rh 2 À X k l¼1 k l À ð1 À cÞ ! jd 0 j 1 þ 4lð1 À cÞ sin 2 rh 2 1 þ 4l sin 2 rh 2 jd 0 j þ 4l sin 2 rh 2 1 þ 4l sin 2 rh 2 ð1 À ð1 À cÞÞjd 0 j ¼ jd 0 j:

For the stability of the scheme, we have Theorem 2. The compact difference scheme defined by ( 10) is unconditionally stable for 0 < c < 1.
Proof. Suppose that e U k is the approximate solution of (10). Applying Lemma 3 and Parseval's equality, we obtain
div.formula: kU k À Ũk k 2 l 2 ¼ kq k k 2 l 2 ¼ X MÀ1 j¼1 hjq k j j 2 ¼ h L 1 À L 0 X MÀ1 j¼1 jd k e irjh j 2 ¼ h L 1 À L 0 X MÀ1 j¼1 jd k j 2 h L 1 À L 0 X MÀ1 j¼1 jd 0 j 2 ¼ h L 1 À L 0 X MÀ1 j¼1
div.p: jd 0 e irjh j 2 ¼ kq 0 k 2 l 2 ¼ kU 0 À Ũ0 k 2 l 2 ; k ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; N which proves that scheme (10) is unconditionally stable. h

div.head: Convergence
div.p: For integer order partial differential equations, by the Lax equivalence theorem it follows then that stability and consistency imply convergence. For the fractional order ones, Lubich [21] proved that the numerical approximation of fractional integrals is convergent of order p if and only if it is stable and consistent of order p. We will prove that the compact finite difference scheme converges with the spatial accuracy of fourth order. For this purpose, we use the following discrete Gronwall Lemma 1.4.2 in [23]). Lemma 4. Assume that k n is a non-negative sequence, and that the sequence / n satisfies / 0 g 0 ;
div.formula: / n g 0 þ P nÀ1 s¼0 p s þ P nÀ1 s¼0 k s / s ; n ! 1: 8 < : Then / n satisfies / 1 g 0 ð1 þ k 0 Þ þ p 0 ; / n g 0 Q nÀ1 s¼0 ð1 þ k s Þ þ P nÀ2 s¼0 p s Q nÀ1 r¼sþ1 ð1 þ k r Þ þ p nÀ1 ; n ! 2: 8 > < > :
div.p: Moreover, if g 0 ! 0 and p n ! 0 for n ! 0, it follows
div.formula: / n ðg 0 þ X nÀ1 s¼0 p s Þ expð X nÀ1 s¼0 k s Þ; n ! 1:
div.p: Now we have Theorem 3. The compact difference scheme defined by ( 10) is first order accurate in time and fourth accurate in the space variable, i.e.,
div.formula: ku k À U k k l 2 Cðs þ h 4 Þ; k ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; N:
div.p: Proof. We conclude from ( 14) that
div.formula: jR k j j Cðk cÀ1 s cÀ1 þ 1Þðs þ h 4 Þ; 1 k N:ð17Þ

Let e k j ¼ u k j À U k j ; 1 j M À 1; e k ¼ ðe k 1 ; e k 2 ; . . . ; e k MÀ1 Þ T ; R k ¼ ðR k 1 ; R k 2 ; . . . ; R k MÀ1 Þ T ; 1 k N, then we have 1 þ 1 12 À l d 2 x u k j À 1 þ 1 12 d 2 x u kÀ1 j ¼ l X k l¼1 k l d 2 x u kÀl j þ s 1 þ 1 12 d 2 x f k j þ s 1 þ 1 12 d 2 x R k j ; 1 j M À 1; 1 k N; and 1 þ 1 12 d 2 x R k j 1 12 R k jÀ1 þ 5 6 R k j þ 1 12 R k jþ1 Cðk cÀ1 s cÀ1 þ 1Þðs þ h 4 Þ: Let e R k ¼ 1 þ 1 12 d 2 x À Á R k 1 ; 1 þ 1 12 d 2 x À Á R k 2 ; Á Á Á ; 1 þ 1 12 d 2 x À Á R k MÀ1 T , then we have Au 1 ¼ e B 0 u 0 þ F 1 þ s e R 1 ; Au k ¼ P kÀ1 l¼0 B l u l þ F k þ s e R k ; k ¼ 2; 3; . . . ; N: 8 > < > :ð18Þ
div.p: Note that e 0 ¼ 0, subtract ( 18) from ( 12), we get
div.formula: Ae 1 ¼ s e R 1 ; Ae k ¼ P kÀ1 l¼1
div.p: B l e l þ s e R k ; k ¼ 2; 3; . . . ; N:
Take the inner product with e 1 and e k respectively, we have

div.p: For any symmetric matrix A, let fk i ðAÞg MÀ1 i¼1 denote the eigenvalues of the matrix A; k min ðAÞ is the smallest eigenvalue and k max ðAÞ is the largest eigenvalue among them, respectively. Note that B l ðl ¼ 0; . . . ; k À 1Þ are also symmetric positive definite because they are symmetric and diagonally dominated, with positive diagonal elements. For any symmetric matrix A, we can use the property of Rayleigh-Ritz ratio, i.e., for any vector x 2 R MÀ1 ; x-0, we have (Theorem 4.2.2 in [24]) k min ðAÞ ðAx; xÞ ðx; xÞ k max ðAÞ:
Thus we obtain

div.p: where k Á k stands for the Euclidean norm (or l 2 norm) on R MÀ1 , i.e., kvk ¼

div.p: We need to know the eigenvalues and eigenvectors for the matrices A; e B 0 and B l ðl ¼ 0; . . . ; k À 1Þ above, all the matrices are tridiagonal ones. In fact, if we define

Therefore, we have, for j ¼ 1; . . . ; M À 1, k j ðAÞ ¼ 10 þ 24l þ 2ð1 À 12lÞ cos jp M ¼ 8 þ 4 cos 2 jp 2M þ 48l sin 2 jp 2M ; k j ðB l Þ ¼ 12lk kÀl À2 þ 2 cos jp M ¼ À48lk kÀl sin 2 jp 2M ; l ¼ 0; 1; . . . ; k À 2; k j ð e B 0 Þ ¼ k j ðB kÀ1 Þ ¼ 10 À 24lk 1 þ 2ð1 þ 12lk 1 Þ cos jp M ¼ 8 þ 4 cos 2 jp 2M À 48lk 1 sin 2 jp 2M :
div.p: From (21), we obtain

div.p: By Lemma 4, we get

div.head: Numerical experiments
div.p: Example 1. We consider the Example 1 given in paper [7],
@uðx;tÞ
div.formula: @t ¼ 0 D 1Àc t @ 2 u @x 2 h i þ e x ð1 þ cÞt c À Cð2þcÞ Cð1þ2cÞ t 2c h i ; 0 < t 1; 0 < x < 1;
div.p: uð0; tÞ ¼ t 1þc ; uð1; tÞ ¼ et 1þc ; 0 t 1;
uðx; 0Þ ¼ 0; 0 x 1;
with the exact solution being uðx; tÞ ¼ e x t 1þc .

Since the l 2 error of our difference scheme is of first order in time and fourth order in space, assume that the error of our scheme satisfies (where C 1 ðuÞ and C 2 ðuÞ depend on the theoretical solution u)
div.formula: ke k k l 2 ¼ X MÀ1 j¼1 je k j j 2 h ! 1=2 ¼ C 1 ðuÞs þ C 2 ðuÞh 4 ;
div.p: then if we decrease the mesh size of h to h=2 and s to s=16, then we get a factor 1=16 for the error ke k k l 2 . Therefore, to test the order of convergence of the scheme (10), we first let h ¼ s ¼ 1=4, then we let h ¼ 1=8; s ¼ 1=64, and h ¼ 1=16 and s ¼ 1=1024 (corresponding to upper half of Tables 1 and2). We also choose another pair of the mesh sizes, starting from h ¼ s ¼ 1=8 (corresponding to lower half of Tables 1 and2).

The results for kek l 2 and kek l 1 ¼ max 1 j MÀ1 jU N j À uðx j ; 1Þj for the final time t ¼ 1 (we abbreviate the superscript N), together with the relative error in brackets, and the experimental convergence order are shown in Tables 1 and2 for c ¼ 0:25 and c ¼ 0:75, respectively.
In these tables, the experimental order of convergence rðs; hÞ is computed by the formula rðs; hÞ ¼ log 2 ðkeð16s; 2hÞk Ã =keðs; hÞk Ã Þ;

and keðs; hÞk Ã means the error kek Ã computed with mesh sizes s and h, with kek Ã ¼ kek l 1 ; kek l 2 or kek l 2 =kuk l 2 . For example, the order of convergence are obtained by data from the first line divided by the second line, and the second divided by the third, respectively, i.e., we get the results for r 1 64 ; 1 8 À Á and r 1 1024 ; 1 16 À Á , respectively. These results are in accordance with the order of convergence of our implicit difference approximation scheme. The numerical solution U were plotted using h ¼ 1 16 ; s ¼ 1 1024 , with c ¼ 0:25 and c ¼ 0:75, respectively, in Figs. 1 and2. To increase the accuracy in time, we give the results with the Richardson extrapolation method given in [8] in Table 3, for the errors in l 2 and l 1 norms at t ¼ 1 (with the l 1 norms in the brackets). For spatially fractional-order diffusion equations, temporally and spatially second-order accurate numerical estimates were obtained in Tadjeran and Meerschaert [25] by the classical Crank-Nicolson method combined with alternating direction implicit method and spatial extrapolation.

In Table 3, we can see that the Richardson extrapolation technique generally works well for increasing the order of local truncation error. We attribute the exceptions for c ¼ 0:5 and c ¼ 0:6 to that the errors are no longer decreased to halves so we tried another two pairs for s ¼ 1=2 and s ¼ 1=4, and the extrapolation is effective now. @uðx;tÞ @t ¼ 0 D 1Àc t @ 2 u @x 2 h i þ f ðx; tÞ; 0 < t 1; 0 < x < 1; uð0; tÞ ¼ 0; uð1; tÞ ¼ 0; 0 t 1; uðx; 0Þ ¼ 0; 0 x 1: The exact solution of the problem (25) is uðx; tÞ ¼ t 2 sinð2pxÞ, and f ðx; tÞ ¼ 2t þ 8p 2 t 1þc Cð2þcÞ sinð2pxÞ. In the numerical computations we let c ¼ 0:5.

As before, the l 2 error ke k k l 2 (with t k ¼ ks), together with the relative errors in brackets, and the experimental convergence order are shown in Table 4. We can see that the experimental convergence order is approximately 4, that is, the results nearly meet our anticipations. Though the coefficient matrix of the unknowns is tridiagonal and the scheme can be easily solved by the Thomas algorithm, we must admit that since all time history must be in memory, the memory requirements are costly, and the computer memory will limit the step sizes. In fact, we have tried to use the ''Short Memory" principle as proposed in [2], but the numerical experiments are not very satisfactory unless sufficiently many previous time steps have been included. The author thanks one referee for pointing out this comment.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this paper we have investigated the stability and accuracy of a compact implicit difference scheme for solving the fractional diffusion equation. This compact implicit difference scheme has the advantage of high accuracy with the coefficient matrix still being a tridiagonal one, therefore, the linear system of equations are easy to solve. We have proved that the method is unconditionally stable for 0 < c < 1. We have also shown that the method has accuracy of four in the spatial grid size and one in the fractional time step. The conclusions are verified by some numerical experiments.

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: The author wants to express his sincere thanks to the anonymous referees and the Associate Editor for their valuable comments and suggestions on an earlier version of this paper.
